Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2014 11:30PM flimsical wrote: DancingVeggie: Have you taken anything to control the diarrhea? I would try some anti-diarrheal if you have it. Oh my I am so sorry this sounds awful. Your fever is not high enough to warrant going to the ER but if you can't get the diarrhea under control and the fever persists, then I'd go to the ER as a precaution. Perhaps you can make it through the night??
Posts.Title: Halaven anyone? JimmieBell Roddy-Brazil

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2014 02:29AM flimsical wrote: I'm trying to figure out this whole neuropathy thing - I have VERY mild numbness in a few tips of fingers, but an odd thing I've noticed is like this weakness in my feet, like, I can't bend and move around my toes like I used to. Not that this is a huge problem, I just find it strange and wonder if it is related to neuropathy? Anyone experience this? My biggest complaint after treatment is fatigue. Wait no, loss of appetite. They both suck, big time. I love food, and I love eating, and to not be able to eat favorite foods or finish a normal portion is very frustrating. I've lost quite a bit of weight, which I did need to lose, but not like this! I don't have that "full feeling" all the time as some have complained about - I actually feel hungry quite often. Sometimes I will purposely wait until I am starving just so I can eat more than I normally can. It's messed up, and I absolutely hate it. I think it contributes quite heavily to how I feel for the day. I rely on Ensure with banana, a lot. Also, I've had two blood transfusions since starting this treatment. My white counts have not "tanked" although they hover low... but my hemoglobin and RBC have.
Posts.Title: Halaven anyone? JimmieBell Roddy-Brazil

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2014 05:28AM flimsical wrote: Sue I forgot to mention - for the headaches, you should get one of those long sock looking things that you can heat up in the microwave... that REALLY helped me with chemo-related headaches when I was on AC. You have to keep microwaving it, but I swear it was helpful!
Posts.Title: Halaven anyone? JimmieBell Roddy-Brazil

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2014 08:36AM flimsical wrote: Hello ladies, I've been reading all of your posts about Halaven. I just started last week. I was supposed to start a clinical trial with a PARP and platinum, but my liver function tests were so bad that I got kicked out before I could even start. So they gave me a smaller does of the Halaven. Here are my liver function tests after one week (one small dose) of Halaven and also Herceptin. Bilirubin went from 6.7 to 2.0 ALT went from 248 to 110 AST went from 538 to 153 Alk phos went down to 204 from 319 So I am pretty encouraged by those numbers. I am also on Herceptin  - I am technically TN but my onc has been convinced that my cancer has behaved like a HER2 cancer and he was able to get me on it.  I'm curious if any of you who also have liver mets had similar good responses with Halaven and if you could tell me about it? Thank you, Lindsay
Posts.Title: Halaven anyone? JimmieBell Roddy-Brazil

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2014 12:00AM - edited Jun 28, 2014 12:01AM by flimsical Delirium - That is so bizarre that is exactly how I feel! Hungry, sometimes starving, but not wanting to eat! It wasn't until like 11 p.m. that I had that fruit and cereal... and it was COLD... I seem to really only want cold things. Plus I knew I'd feel terrible if I went to bed starving. Ugh. I already lost 15-20 lbs when I was ill from the liver troubles, I am worried about losing more. I am technically still overweight (I think last checked I was 168 and I am 5'6") but losing weight like this just isn't healthy, not to mention the inevitable muscle mass loss. I never in my life thought I would lost weight from having "anorexic symptoms." I've always had a more than adequate appetite. Oh and I gained about 20lbs on AC/T as well! Stupid steroids. I am very surprised you haven't gotten your appetite back yet, I really hope that changes for you soon!! What treatment regimen are you currently on? I apologize if you already wrote that elsewhere but I am so tired and don't feel like looking. Ha ha.
Posts.Title: Halaven anyone? JimmieBell Roddy-Brazil

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2014 05:26AM flimsical wrote: Hi Sue - I feel like I'm learning to "deal" with the fatigue, however this is my OFF week so I am obviously going to be doing better than an on week. Haha. I honestly just hate that the schedule is 2 weeks on 1 week off... I mean, that one week is just not enough to feel better, you know? Have you - or anyone else here - experienced a different treatment schedule? I know I'm getting ahead of myself, but if this drug really is working (need to hear CT results from today, ugh), I wonder if my oncologist would agree to a 2 weeks on 2 weeks off type of schedule? That would be like a freaking vacation!!! As far as this neuropathy, yes I really hope that it remains at this mild level. I have heard stories of how bad it can be and I do not want to lose function of my fingers and toes, or worse, have trouble walking! Why do these drugs that can do so good, make us feel so bad? Why is this the way it has to be?? Sue I am so sorry that you are dealing with lymphedema in your leg as well! I have lymphedema on my axillary dissection side, but fortunately it has not been an issue for me yet. The worst was right after that surgery I was in Vegas - walking a lot - and I had hand swelling. I was diagnosed after I got back, got the sleeve/gauntlet, and wore them maybe a handful of times. I only wear it when flying! My swelling is so slight you cannot even notice it unless you carried around a measuring tape....but I should probably start wearing the damn sleeve. It's just one more thing, you know? Do you have to wear a compression sock for your leg swelling?? I suppose that would be easy to hide with pants and such!!
Posts.Title: Halaven anyone? JimmieBell Roddy-Brazil

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2014 12:19AM flimsical wrote: my hair is slowly falling out after two half doses of halaven ... I'm not gonna shave my head yet though in case it just thins, I am just gonna trim it shorter for now.
Posts.Title: Halaven anyone? JimmieBell Roddy-Brazil

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2014 04:42AM flimsical wrote: HEY How is everyone doing with Halaven? milehigh - I lost my hair at the standard 2 week mark. :-(  I am sick of being bald!!! I got my CT results - everything in the liver has shrunk, so we're onto something! Liver numbers are still good. Hoping I get tumor markers checked next time around. The scan didn't say much about my bone mets except that they were "not perceptibly different." But apparently that doesn't mean it hasn't done anything. I hope I can get a bone scan before December (that's when my next one is supposed to be), because that is way too long to wait!!! I can't get MRI's because I still have tissue expanders in... I never made it long before stage 4 dx to get my reconstruction. Also, my neuropathy in my feet was worsening enough for them to reduce my dose by 20% for the foreseeable future. I would rather have a lower dose and no neuropathy rather than having to stop taking a drug that is WORKING. They also have me taking 200mg of B6 daily. It's mostly a numbness but there is some pain associated with it. If I don't move around enough, I can feel it in my calves. I will take a 5mg Oxycodone if it hurts enough. Anyone else dealing with this? Anyone have any stories/side-effects/good news to share?! Oh in other good news, there's a woman in one of my Facebook groups that has been NED for a year on Halaven!!! They are talking about giving her more of a break - 2 weeks on 2 weeks off. So, there is hope!!! I'm going to the beach next week for my "off week" - can't wait to relax in the sun and sand! Hope everyone is well!
Posts.Title: Halaven anyone? JimmieBell Roddy-Brazil

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2014 11:16PM flimsical wrote: Had my first infusion of cycle 2 on Wednesday. I am so unbelievable tired, it's crazy! I did have friends visiting since Wednesday...with their babies...which probably didn't help, but man the fatigue is unreal. I had only gotten half doses my first cycle, plus I was so sick already from liver issues that I couldn't tell if I was experiencing any side effects from the halaven or not. Now that my liver is "normal" I know that this fatigue is 100% from the chemo. I guess there could be worse things, and I am lucky to not be experiencing nausea.  I'm sorry Tina and DancingVeggie that you have nausea so bad!!! That is awful. I was told that you cannot take Zofran with Halaven - something to do with the drugs' interaction with each other, I didn't fully hear when the nurse was explaining it. So I think you'd have to ask for a different med. I was told that Ativan helps. I take it anyway to help me calm down, and even to help me sleep sometimes. Can everyone tell me what days are the worst for them? I think today (two days after) has been the worst so far. I was kinda tired the past two days but not quite like this. I took at least two naps today, and I'm about ready for bed again only an hour or so after waking from my last nap. I also had a hard time eating today, despite being hungry! It's very weird. My mom made this delicious vegetable pasta, and right as the fork touched my mouth my stomach started to hurt. Even though I was hungry! It's awful. I had an Ensure shake just so I had some nutrition, and then later on had some cereal and a bowl of fruit. Anyone lose their appetite, or have weird stomach issues?? DancingVeggie- were you given a prescription for a local anesthetic cream (lidocaine) to put on your port before treatment? I was given one and told to put it on an hour before your appointment, and cover it with plastic wrap so it stays on there. It REALLY helps avoid that pain when they access your port. I forgot to put it on this week and I really regretted that. If you don't already have it, definitely ask. I didn't know they gave you Neupogen through your port - I always got Neulasta in my arm?? Hmm.
Posts.Title: Halaven anyone? JimmieBell Roddy-Brazil

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2014 04:13AM flimsical wrote: I had a CT last week to determine how many more RT I need -- everything looked good on that front, but the radiologist noted a small spot on my spine that they want to follow up with an MRI. I am beyond terrified - my rad onc talked me down and said that he would have normally overlooked this on another patient but because of my history he feels it necessary to rule out mets. He even showed me the CT. The spot really does look small - like 8 mm x 2 mm - and it's inside a vertebrae from what I can tell. But it was barely even a shadow on the scan. I am having a really hard time dealing with this even though nothing has been determined yet. I would normally think positively but I just can't see a positive outcome!!! I know it's common to get faulty scans and overzealous radiologists but I can barely function, this is consuming my mind. I JUST had a CT six weeks ago and nothing abnormal was noted.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2014 12:20PM flimsical wrote: THANK YOU Chrissy - I just have to make it through the next few days. Worrying will get me nowhere I realize... but damn is it hard. I think what scares me the most is the mere possibility of having to tell my family. It's the most debilitating fear I've ever experienced and I appreciate your input, you talked me down.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2014 01:28AM flimsical wrote: Hello everyone. I've been avoiding posting here/asking questions because I've been living in the town of Denial these past several weeks. As soon as I finished radiation mid-late January, I started on Xeloda as a precautionary drug (long story) but also because I'm TNBC and had sneaky positive nodes that were found two months after my surgery. After the first week I had this crazy localized back pain that went away after about 4-5 days. I went and saw a chiropractor which seemed to help. I did yoga stretches, also helped. Then it moved around. It has not been consistent but has gone from middle back to low back, and so on. Currently my chief complaint is stiffness. In my back, hips - and worse after I've slept through the night. I am constantly "on high alert" so I think I am probably making it worse by being afraid of certain movement. If I slip or trip, I seize up immediately for fear of hurting myself, which as you can imagine just makes it worse. I use a heating pad and take ibuprofen which helps, but obviously the thought has been on my mind that it is bone mets. And honestly at this point I feel that if it isn't, I will be so shocked that I will probably go skydiving naked or jump in a river and scream with joy. Those things are unrelated but you get the idea. Anyway - I've read so many posts about post-treatment effects, drug side-effects, radiation affecting your back, etc... and I could be lumped into any of those categories, really. I have an appointment with my onc next Wednesday - my last appointment in late Feb went fine, he seemed unconcerned about my pain, probably because at that point it was new. When I mentioned to the nurse practitioner that it could be the Xeloda, she brushed it off, even though back pain/stiffness is listed as a side-effect!! Anyway, I assume my blood counts were fine because I got no call about that either. I know that I need to ask for a bone scan - which I swear I will do -  I guess I'm just asking if anyone wants to talk me off the ledge? I'm only 31. This blows.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2014 01:52PM flimsical wrote: Chrissy ... Simply, thank you. You are a gift. :-) Also, scheduled a massage. Gonna give it a try.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: May 20, 2013 07:01PM flimsical wrote: Hello everyone -- I am on Taxotere #2 (every 21 days). I've developed a low-grade fever the Sunday after both Thursday treatments. Last time it hovered around 99.5 all of Monday, and was back to normal by Tuesday. It seems to be doing the same this time. I know it was higher than that overnight -- at one point I checked and it was 100.3 but I refused to check again because I really didn't want to go to the ER (I'm stubborn). When I talked to the NP about it before my last treatment, she said it shouldn't have anything to do with low counts since I get Neulasta and my counts have been normal. It's also worth mentioning that I did not develop a fever at all during my AC treatments with Neulasta. Has anyone else experienced this? Help!
Posts.Title: April 2013 Chemo Group BeHereNow 6cats

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2014 02:08PM flimsical wrote: Hi everyone -  I was reading back a little bit and there was some discussion about receiving Herceptin for her2-low. I am one of those people... I am receiving Halaven and Herceptin because my oncologist is one of those docs that are convinced it will help certain patients. He thinks my cancer "acted" like a her2 cancer. I wish I could reiterate what he told me to articulate this better. Either way, my her2 score was 1+ and my ratio is 1.48.  My liver enzymes were through the roof prior to starting treatment (we thought there was a blockage but they couldn't seem to find one with the ultrasound). After just one infusion of the Halaven and Herceptin, my enzymes came way down. AST went from 538 to 153, ALT went from 248 to 110, and Alk Phos went from 319 to 204. Most importantly I think, however, is that my Bilirubin went from 6.7 to 2.0!! That was scary... my eyes were yellow and everything. My liver actually hurt. I just had my second infusion last week, and had labs today. I am pretty anxious about hearing the results of these labs. I really hope that those numbers continue to go down. So, I have no idea if the Herceptin has anything to do with it - but for all intents and purposes I am still considered triple negative. The reason I'm writing all of this is because I'm curious if anyone else has any similar experiences?? Whether you were on a trial for her2 low or anything having to do with triple negative and herceptin. Thanks!
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2014 10:11AM flimsical wrote: Cat-- I think the approval of Herceptin for me had to do with some genomic testing that showed I had SOME HER2 in my cancer. I forget the word he used, I want to say homogenous but that doesn't sound right. I should have taken a recorder in my appointments so I could understand why I was able to get this drug despite still being considered TN!! Either way genomic testing is important and everyone should be able to get it. Eventually it'll be standard of care and everything will be personalized. It needs to happen faster. I think my onc is trying to get me the FoundationOne testing that shows what drugs will and will not work. That's what needs to be standard.
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2014 03:53PM flimsical wrote: Hi slowloris, I'm curious about your clinical trials! Especially the first one. What qualified you to be in it, and why did you decide to participate? I see you were already on carbo/gem and Halaven. I'm on Halaven now for liver and bone mets. How long did Halaven work for you? I am hoping to eventually get on an ABT-888 trial. I got kicked out of one before I even started because of my liver enzymes. Also, I have TP53 gene as well, and I think my oncologist is sending for more of some kind of testing - something that he learned about at ASCO this past conference. Anyway, hope you are doing well. I am feeling a lot better than I had been... had a blood transfusion a week ago and it's finally "taking effect" and I'm not debilitatingly tired, so that's good. -Lindsay (I posted right above you as well)
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2014 11:05PM flimsical wrote: Hopeful65: Has your oncologist suggested Carboplatin/Gemzar? A LOT of triple negative women have had great success with that drug combination. Please ask your oncologist about it. It is rough on your counts so you would probably have to get Neulasta/Neupogen but I actually don't think you would lose your hair. The next route after that could possibly be Eribulin (Halaven) which is what I'm currently on. We think it's working but I don't have scans for another few weeks so I won't really know until then. Do you have the BRCA mutation? You should absolutely get the FoundationOne testing if you have the means. Did you get results yet?? If you are BRCA positive, you should ask about PARP inhibitor trials. PARP is showing great promise with TN and BRCA patients. I have a friend on a PARP trial who has had 72% regression in like only 4 cycles of the treatment on liver and bone mets. It's a combination of Carboplatin, Taxol and the PARP inhibitor. There are other trials that have different drugs, some that have the PARP only... but you have options!!! Please don't think you are out of options!!!! Where has your cancer spread?? Please don't lose hope! Stay positive!! -Lindsay
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama
